title: Investigating the Adaptive Robustness with Knowledge Conflicts in LLM-based Multi-Agent Systems
author: Tianjie Ju (Shanghai Jiao Tong University), Bowen Wang (Shanghai Jiao Tong University), Hao Fei (National University of Singapore), Mong-Li Lee (National University of Singapore), Wynne Hsu (National University of Singapore), Yun Li (Cognitive AI Lab), Qianren Wang (Cognitive AI Lab), Pengzhou Cheng (Shanghai Jiao Tong University), Zongru Wu (Shanghai Jiao Tong University), Zhuosheng Zhang (Shanghai Jiao Tong University), Gongshen Liu (Shanghai Jiao Tong University)
relevance_why: The exploration of adaptive robustness through knowledge conflicts in multi-agent systems may inform collaborative strategies in audio processing and music generation tasks, potentially enhancing the resilience of AI models against knowledge discrepancies.
background: This paper explores the robustness of large language model (LLM)-based multi-agent systems when confronted with knowledge conflicts, enabling these agents to collaborate on complex tasks.
contribution: This study introduces a novel analysis of knowledge conflicts in multi-agent systems, demonstrating their role in enhancing collaborative decision-making and adaptive robustness.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily focused on either single-agent systems or did not address inherent knowledge conflicts within multi-agent setups, often overlooking collaboration dynamics.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work systematically evaluates the impact of both mild and task-critical knowledge conflicts, providing comprehensive metrics and showing surprising resilience in decision-making under conflict.

key_innovation: It uniquely identifies that knowledge conflicts can act as drivers of enhanced decision-making capabilities rather than mere obstacles.
real_world_impact: Findings from this research could lead to more resilient AI systems in real-world applications like collaborative programming, automated coding, and potentially improving human-AI collaboration in creative domains.
limitations: The authors note that the study is limited to specific tasks and models, calling for future research to explore more diverse agent interactions and tasks.

new_terms.large language model (LLM): **Large language model (LLM)** refers to AI models designed to generate and understand human-like text based on extensive training datasets.
new_terms.multi-agent systems (MAS): **Multi-agent systems (MAS)** involve multiple autonomous agents interacting and cooperating to solve problems.

open_sourcing: The code is publicly available at https://github.com/wbw625/MultiAgentRobustness.
